programs.program_name: MISO Load Modifying Resources (LMR) - Kentucky Territory
programs.description: Load Modifying Resources (LMR) participate in MISO's capacity market (Planning Resource Auction) to provide resource adequacy. LMRs are demand response resources that can reduce load during emergency conditions to help maintain grid reliability. LMRs include both demand response (LMR-DR) and behind-the-meter generation (LMR-BTMG). IMPORTANT NOTE: Major Kentucky utilities LG&E and KU withdrew from MISO in 2006. This program is only available to Big Rivers Electric Corporation service territory and other MISO-member utilities in Kentucky.

service_territories: Big Rivers Electric Corporation service territory only
Note: Louisville Gas & Electric (LG&E) and Kentucky Utilities (KU) are NOT MISO members as of 2024

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Minimum 100 kW load reduction capability required. Commercial and industrial customers eligible if they can meet minimum capacity and performance requirements.

seasonal_rates.notes: Highest price in MISO history. Uniform clearing across all zones including Zone 6. Uses new Reliability-Based Demand Curve (RBDC) methodology.

performance_rate.notes: LMRs registered solely as capacity resources do NOT receive energy market payments. They are emergency-only resources with no must-offer requirement into energy markets.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: LMRs that fail to perform during emergency events face capacity accreditation reductions based on historical performance. Resources requiring more than 6 hours notification time are ineligible for capacity accreditation. Resources requiring 4-6 hours notification receive only 50% capacity credit. Beginning with PY 2023-24, resources must respond within 6 hours or lose accreditation entirely. MISO's Independent Market Monitor has documented significant non-performance issues, with over 40% of DRR Type I resources failing to perform adequately in 2023-24. Since 2019, enforcement actions have been taken against market manipulation, resulting in several participants exiting the market. New reforms require attestation by company officers to prevent fraud and market manipulation.

seasons.notes: Peak risk season. LMRs are most likely to be called during summer peak demand periods, typically 2:00 PM to 6:00 PM.
Secondary risk season for winter peak events

call_windows.notes: Typical peak demand period when LMR accreditation is measured

event_parameters.notes: LMRs must be capable of maintaining targeted demand reduction continuously for at least 4 consecutive hours. Must respond to MISO instructions within 6 hours or less notification time. Resources must be capable of being interrupted at least 5 times during Planning Year when called by MISO. New LMR Type I category (effective PY 2028-29) for long lead time resources requiring 6 hours notification, deployed during Energy Emergency Alerts.

nomination_bidding.nomination_deadline: Registration and accreditation must be completed prior to each Planning Year. Annual Planning Resource Auction occurs in spring for following Planning Year (June-May).
nomination_bidding.bidding_structure: LMRs bid into MISO's annual Planning Resource Auction (PRA) by zone. Clearing prices are determined by supply-demand balance using new Reliability-Based Demand Curve (RBDC) methodology beginning PY 2025-26. Resources can bid at different price points. Uniform clearing price applies to all cleared resources in each zone and season.

enrollment_period.notes: PY 2025-26 auction held April 2025. Resources must be registered in Module E Capacity Tracking (MECT) tool prior to auction participation.

special_attributes: New DLOL-based accreditation methodology to begin PY 2028-29
Zonal Resource Credits (ZRC) represent capacity contribution
No must-offer requirement into energy markets for LMR-only resources
Can optionally participate in energy and ancillary services markets
LMRs may only be aggregated up to Load Zone CPNode level
Certified Market Participants only - requires Module E access

program_evolution.change_description: Louisville Gas & Electric (LG&E) and Kentucky Utilities (KU) withdrew from MISO, significantly reducing Kentucky participation in MISO capacity markets
FERC Order 841 established 100 kW minimum size for Electric Storage Resources, aligning with LMR minimum
FERC approved seasonal capacity requirements and LMR performance requirements
Implemented seasonal accreditation (Seasonal Accredited Capacity - SAC) for PY 2023-24. Reduced notification time requirement from 12 hours to 6 hours maximum.

Major LMR reform initiatives (RASC-2019-9). MISO filed with FERC to implement DLOL-based accreditation methodology effective PY 2028-29. Introduced new LMR Type I category for 6-hour notification resources. Enhanced data requirements and attestation by company officers to prevent fraud. Significant enforcement actions against market manipulation reduced DRR participation.

First auction using Reliability-Based Demand Curve (RBDC) methodology. Summer capacity prices reached historic high of $666.50/MW-day across all zones. Fast-tracked elimination of Emergency Demand Response (EDR) program for PY 2025-26.
Planned implementation of new DLOL-based resource accreditation methodology following 3-year transition period starting September 2024

program_history.notes: As of 2023, MISO had 7,695 MW registered as LMR-DR and 4,129 MW registered as LMR-BTMG. Since 2019, DR resources have received $800 million in capacity payments across the entire MISO footprint.

data_sources.source_name: MISO Business Practices Manual BPM-026 (Demand Response)
MISO Resource Accreditation White Paper Version 2.1
MISO 2024 State of the Market Report
Kentucky Public Service Commission LG&E/KU MISO Withdrawal Order

integration_metadata.notes: HIGH QUALITY DATA from official MISO sources. Battery suitability: EXCELLENT for behind-the-meter non-injecting battery systems. Batteries can participate as LMR-BTMG (behind-the-meter generation) if they do not inject to the grid. CRITICAL LIMITATION: Major Kentucky utilities LG&E and KU are NOT MISO members, severely limiting geographic availability. Only Big Rivers Electric Corporation service territory qualifies. For most Kentucky locations, this program is NOT AVAILABLE. Historical clearing prices show high volatility: $0.75-$34.10/MW-day in 2024-25, jumping to $666.50/MW-day in 2025-26 (22x increase). 4-hour minimum event duration and 6-hour notification requirement are well-suited to battery capabilities. New reforms and enhanced monitoring reduce fraud risk. Strong program documentation and regulatory oversight. Recommend confirming utility membership in MISO before investing in optimization for this program.

programs.program_name: MISO Demand Response Resources Type II (DRR-II) - Kentucky Territory
programs.description: Demand Response Resources Type II (DRR-II) participate in MISO's energy and ancillary services markets, providing economic demand response that follows MISO dispatch instructions. DRR-II resources can deliver varying levels of output, provide telemetered data, and respond to 5-minute dispatch signals. They can provide energy, regulating reserves, spinning reserves, and supplemental reserves. DRR-II resources that clear the Planning Resource Auction have must-offer requirements into day-ahead and real-time energy markets. IMPORTANT: Only available in Big Rivers Electric Corporation service territory - LG&E and KU are not MISO members.

service_territories: Big Rivers Electric Corporation service territory only
Note: Louisville Gas & Electric (LG&E) and Kentucky Utilities (KU) are NOT MISO members

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Must be capable of providing telemetered output data and following 5-minute dispatch instructions. Suitable for flexible loads and battery energy storage systems.

capacity_rate.notes: Same capacity clearing prices as LMR if resource clears Planning Resource Auction. See LMR program entry for seasonal capacity rates. DRR-II resources can choose to participate in capacity market or energy-only.

performance_rate.notes: DRR-II resources receive Locational Marginal Price (LMP) for energy delivered, subject to Net Benefits Price Threshold (NBPT). Only paid if Real-Time Ex Post LMP is equal to or above NBPT. NBPT ranges from $28-$52/MWh historically (monthly values published by MISO). MISO proposes prohibiting DRR offers below NBPT to prevent gaming. Energy offer cap: $2,000/MWh, offer floor: -$500/MWh. Ancillary services payments: Regulating Reserve offer cap $500/MWh (floor $0), Contingency Reserve (spinning/supplemental) offer cap $100/MWh (floor $0). Historical spinning reserve ~$4/MWh, supplemental ~$1.50/MWh (2019 data). DRRs can clear up to 40% of spinning reserve requirement.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: DRR-II resources face economic withholding penalties if they deviate from Reference Level calculations per Module D of MISO Tariff. Resources that cleared PRA and fail to meet must-offer requirements face capacity payment reductions. MISO Independent Market Monitor (IMM) found 40%+ of DRR Type I resources did not perform adequately during 213 spinning reserve deployments in 2023-24. Enhanced data requirements now mandate hourly meter data for all event and non-event hours for last 45 days, updated every fortnight. Market manipulation enforcement has been significant - payments to DRRs fell from peak to $4.8 million in 2024 as investigated resources ceased participating. New requirements include officer attestation to prevent fraud.

seasons.notes: DRR-II participates in day-ahead and real-time energy markets continuously, not limited to seasonal events

call_windows.notes: DRR-II resources receive continuous 5-minute dispatch signals during operating hours

event_parameters.notes: DRR-II resources follow 5-minute setpoint instructions from MISO. Must provide telemetered output data. Can deliver varying levels of output (not just on/off). Participates in MISO's co-optimized energy and ancillary services market. Can provide regulating reserves, spinning reserves, and supplemental reserves including ramp products.

nomination_bidding.nomination_deadline: Day-ahead market bids due day prior. Real-time market offers submitted continuously.
nomination_bidding.bidding_structure: DRR-II resources submit energy offers into Day-Ahead Market and/or Real-Time Market. Must offer into Day-Ahead Energy Market if they clear the MISO PRA (capacity market). Can submit offer curves with multiple price-quantity pairs. For Operating Reserves, must submit reserve availability offer with pricing information ($/MW for capacity reservation, capped at $250/MW). MISO proposes prohibiting offers through self-scheduling or below NBPT threshold to prevent gaming.

enrollment_period.notes: Must register as Certified Market Participant through Module E before participation

special_attributes: Co-optimized with energy and ancillary services
Can provide multiple ancillary service products simultaneously
Must-offer requirements if cleared capacity auction
Subject to Reference Level calculations for economic withholding
Enhanced meter data requirements (hourly data for 45 days)

program_evolution.change_description: Major reforms proposed to address market manipulation concerns (MSC-2024-6). Proposals include: prohibiting DRR offers below NBPT, enhanced hourly meter data requirements for all hours (not just events), modification of Reference Level calculations, and economic withholding thresholds. MISO intends to file with FERC in early 2025. Enforcement actions resulted in significant reduction in DRR participation - payments fell to $4.8 million in 2024 from much higher levels as manipulative resources exited.
Independent Market Monitor documented significant performance issues - 40%+ of DRR Type I resources failed to perform adequately during spinning reserve deployments

program_history.notes: DRR participation has declined significantly due to enforcement actions. Total payments to all DRRs in MISO fell to just $4.8 million in 2024.

data_sources.source_name: MISO Business Practices Manual BPM-026 (Demand Response)
MSC: Demand Response Participating as a Supply Resource (MSC-2024-6)
MISO 2024 State of the Market Report
MISO Energy and Ancillary Services Co-optimization

integration_metadata.notes: HIGH QUALITY DATA from official MISO sources. Battery suitability: EXCELLENT for advanced battery systems with fast response and telemetry capabilities. DRR-II is ideal for battery energy storage systems that can follow 5-minute dispatch signals and provide ancillary services (regulating reserves, spinning reserves). CRITICAL LIMITATION: Geographic availability extremely limited - only Big Rivers Electric Corporation territory qualifies, as LG&E and KU withdrew from MISO in 2006. Must-offer requirements may reduce scheduling flexibility if resource clears capacity auction. NBPT ($28-$52/MWh) creates payment threshold that may limit revenue opportunities during low-price hours. Recent enforcement actions and enhanced monitoring requirements increase compliance burden but improve market integrity. Enhanced meter data requirements (hourly data for 45 days, updated bi-weekly) require robust metering infrastructure. Proposed reforms to prohibit offers below NBPT may further constrain bidding strategies. Market participation declining due to enforcement - total DRR payments only $4.8M in 2024. Strong API integration available for automated dispatch. Recommend detailed analysis of NBPT impact on revenues and confirmation of Big Rivers service territory before optimization investment.

programs.program_name: MISO Emergency Demand Response (EDR) - Kentucky Territory
programs.description: Emergency Demand Response (EDR) was a program allowing load reductions and behind-the-meter generation to be dispatched during emergency conditions (NERC Energy Emergency Alert Level 2 or 3). EDR resources had no capacity credits or must-offer requirements and were compensated from energy markets when dispatched. IMPORTANT: MISO eliminated the EDR program effective Planning Year 2025-26. This program is NO LONGER AVAILABLE. Additionally, this was only ever available in Big Rivers Electric Corporation service territory, as LG&E and KU are not MISO members.

service_territories: MISO Local Resource Zone (LRZ) 6 (Indiana-Kentucky portion) - PROGRAM DISCONTINUED
Big Rivers Electric Corporation service territory only
Note: Louisville Gas & Electric (LG&E) and Kentucky Utilities (KU) were never MISO members

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: PROGRAM DISCONTINUED - No longer accepting participants

performance_rate.notes: EDR resources were compensated at energy market LMP when dispatched. EDR Offer Cap was set to Value of Lost Load (VOLL), which was $3,500/MWh. MISO proposed decoupling EDR Offer Cap from VOLL and keeping EDR cap at $3,500/MWh even as VOLL increased to $10,000/MWh. However, these reforms became moot with program elimination.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: EDR resources had no capacity obligations and therefore no non-performance penalties. However, program was eliminated before proposed penalty structures could be implemented.

event_parameters.notes: EDR was called during NERC Energy Emergency Alert 2 or 3 events. Market Participants submitted EDR offers day prior indicating availability. MISO never called upon EDRs in its operational history.

enrollment_period.notes: Program eliminated for Planning Year 2025-26 (effective June 1, 2025)

special_attributes: Never called upon in MISO operational history
Had no capacity credits or must-offer requirements
Defined in Schedule 30 of MISO Tariff (now obsolete)

program_evolution.change_description: MISO proposed reforms to shortage pricing including decoupling EDR Offer Cap from VOLL. Proposed increasing VOLL from $3,500/MWh to $10,000/MWh while keeping EDR cap at $3,500/MWh.

MISO decided to eliminate Emergency Demand Response program as part of LMR reform package (RASC-2019-9). Fast-tracked elimination for Planning Year 2025-26 (effective June 1, 2025). EDRs never called upon in MISO history, making program elimination relatively non-controversial.

program_history.notes: EDR program eliminated because it was never utilized in MISO's operational history. Resources that previously participated as EDRs can transition to LMR or DRR registration if they meet eligibility requirements.

data_sources.source_name: MSC: EDR Offer Cap Options and VOLL Circuit Breaker
MISO Updated Shortage Pricing White Paper
data_sources.url: https://cdn.misoenergy.org/MISO Updated Shortage Pricing White Paper - Nov 2024663437.pdf

integration_metadata.notes: PROGRAM DISCONTINUED - DO NOT INCLUDE IN OPTIMIZATION MODELS. This program was eliminated effective Planning Year 2025-26 (June 1, 2025) and is no longer available for any Kentucky participants. Historical data quality is high due to official MISO documentation, but program has zero future applicability. MISO never called upon EDR resources in operational history, confirming the program's limited utility. Resources should transition to LMR or DRR-II programs if eligible and if located in Big Rivers Electric Corporation service territory. Battery suitability assessment: NOT APPLICABLE - program discontinued.

research_summary.geographic_coverage: EXTREMELY LIMITED - Only Big Rivers Electric Corporation service territory in Kentucky. LG&E and KU (serving majority of Kentucky population) are NOT MISO members.
research_summary.data_quality_assessment: High quality data from official MISO sources including BPM-026, Planning Resource Auction results, stakeholder presentations, and FERC filings. Data completeness: 8.5/10. All three MISO DR product types documented with detailed program rules, pricing history, and recent reform initiatives. Kentucky-specific limitation clearly identified.
research_summary.battery_suitability_summary: MISO DR programs are technically excellent for battery energy storage systems. LMR program ideal for 4-hour battery systems with 6-hour notification capability. DRR-II program excellent for advanced batteries with fast response (5-minute dispatch) and telemetry. However, CRITICAL GEOGRAPHIC LIMITATION severely restricts applicability: only Big Rivers Electric Corporation territory qualifies. LG&E and KU withdrew from MISO in 2006, eliminating access for majority of Kentucky. Capacity prices highly volatile: $0.75-$34.10/MW-day in 2024-25, jumping to $666.50/MW-day in 2025-26. NBPT threshold ($28-$52/MWh) may limit DRR-II revenue opportunities. Recent enforcement actions and enhanced monitoring requirements increase compliance burden. EDR program discontinued entirely. Overall recommendation: Confirm utility membership in MISO before any investment in MISO DR optimization for Kentucky batteries.
key_findings: Major Kentucky utilities (LG&E, KU) are NOT MISO members as of 2006 - severely limits program availability
Only Big Rivers Electric Corporation territory participates in MISO Kentucky
Three DR product types: LMR (capacity-focused), DRR-II (energy/AS-focused), EDR (discontinued)
Historic capacity price increase: 22x jump from 2024-25 to 2025-26 ($30 to $666.50/MW-day summer)
LMR requires 100 kW minimum, 4-hour event duration, 6-hour maximum notification
DRR-II provides 5-minute dispatch capability for energy and ancillary services
NBPT ($28-$52/MWh) creates payment threshold limiting DRR-II revenue in low-price hours
EDR program eliminated effective PY 2025-26 - never called in MISO history
Significant enforcement actions in 2024 reduced DRR participation due to market manipulation
New DLOL-based accreditation methodology coming PY 2028-29
Must-offer requirements for DRR-II resources that clear capacity auction
Enhanced meter data requirements: hourly data for 45 days, updated bi-weekly
40%+ non-performance rate documented for some DR resources in 2023-24
research_summary.researcher_notes: This research uncovered a critical limitation that dramatically reduces the value of MISO DR programs for most Kentucky battery operators. While MISO has robust and well-documented demand response programs with strong battery suitability, the geographic availability is extremely limited due to LG&E and KU's 2006 withdrawal from MISO. Only Big Rivers Electric Corporation service territory participates. This finding should be prominently featured in any Kentucky battery optimization analysis. Data quality is high (8.5/10) with comprehensive official documentation from MISO stakeholder meetings, business practices manuals, auction results, and FERC filings. All pricing data is actual auction results (not estimates). Program rules are clearly documented in BPM-026. Recent reform initiatives (2024-2025) indicate active program evolution with focus on preventing market manipulation and improving performance accountability. The 22x capacity price increase from 2024-25 to 2025-26 reflects MISO's new RBDC methodology and tightening reserves, creating significant revenue opportunity for qualified participants. However, geographic limitation remains the dominant consideration for Kentucky applications.
